title: The Impact of Dependent Interviewing on Interview Dynamics: Implications for Longitudinal Survey Design
abstractText:
Dependent interviewing (DI) is a survey design tool by which researchers word questions or route respondents through a questionnaire "depending" on information previously gathered from the respondent. Question wordings, in particular, are affected by in-filling the respondent's previously gathered information.

This design feature is increasingly used where a sample of respondents are re-interviewed over time as with a longitudinal or panel design. However, little is known about the effect of DI on the interaction between interviewers and respondents or how variation in this interaction might affect data quality.

Focusing on this gap in understanding, we will examine transcripts derived from a pilot for Wave 16 of the British Household Panel Study. Applying a technique known as sequence analysis, we will disentangle the effect of dependent interviewing on survey respondents, interviewers and the dynamic between them. 

We will also investigate the associations between any problematic interview dynamics and the characteristics of interviewers and respondents. We will further analyse the associations between any problematic dynamics and indicators of data quality. Our overarching aim is to help inform better questionnaire design and ultimately the quality of data collected.
